question_details.query: What is the combined effect on peatland vegetation of changing both the type of livestock and the season of grazing?

summary_details.relevant_summary: No studies have evaluated the effects on peatland vegetation of changing the season or timing of livestock grazing [1737]. No studies have evaluated the effects on peatland vegetation of changing livestock type [1736].
summary_statements: No studies have evaluated the effects on peatland vegetation of changing the season or timing of livestock grazing.
No studies have evaluated the effects on peatland vegetation of changing livestock type.

question_details.query: What is the impact of reintroducing beavers on the vegetation of Patagonian peatlands?

summary_details.relevant_summary: No studies were found that directly evaluate the effects of reintroducing beavers on the vegetation of Patagonian peatlands. Related evidence gaps include: no evidence for the effects of introducing beavers to impede water flow in forest watercourses on forests [1187]; and no studies evaluating the effects on marsh/swamp vegetation of reintroducing overharvested animals [3018].
summary_statements: No studies were found that directly evaluate the effects of reintroducing beavers on the vegetation of Patagonian peatlands.
There is no evidence for the effects on forests of introducing beavers to impede water flow in forest watercourses.
No studies evaluate the effects on marsh/swamp vegetation of reintroducing overharvested animals.

question_details.query: What are the long-term effects (over 30 years) of using prescribed fire to control problematic plants on bog vegetation composition?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across five bog studies evaluating prescribed fire to control problematic plants, reported vegetation responses included: higher moss cover (including Sphagnum) in plots burned more often in a UK bog, and increased moss/lichen/bare ground cover 2–7 months after burning in Germany [1774]. Cottongrass cover was unchanged 2–7 months after burning in Germany, increased 8–18 years after burning in the UK, and was similar between plots burned every 10 or 20 years in the same UK bog [1774]. Heather cover was lower in plots burned more often in a UK bog and lower in burned than unburned plots in Germany; cover of other shrubs was not affected in Germany [1774]. Vegetation structure responses in a UK bog included more grass-like biomass but less total vegetation, shrub and bryophyte biomass in more frequently burned plots [1774]. Plant species richness in a UK bog was reduced or limited by burning [1774]. Reported bog study timeframes included short-term (2–7 months) and multi-year (8–18 years) measurements [1774].
summary_statements: In a UK bog, plots burned more often had higher moss cover, including Sphagnum.
In a German study, there was increased moss, lichen, and bare ground cover 2–7 months after burning.
Cottongrass cover was unchanged 2–7 months after burning in Germany.
Cottongrass cover increased 8–18 years after burning in the UK.
Cottongrass cover was similar between plots burned every 10 or 20 years in the same UK bog.
Heather cover was lower in plots burned more often in a UK bog.
Heather cover was lower in burned plots than in unburned plots in Germany.
The cover of other shrubs was not affected by burning in Germany.
In a UK bog, more frequently burned plots had more grass-like biomass.
More frequently burned plots in a UK bog had less total vegetation, shrub and bryophyte biomass.
Plant species richness in a UK bog was reduced or limited by burning.
Reported bog study timeframes included short-term measurements of 2–7 months.
Reported bog study timeframes included multi-year measurements of 8–18 years.
